DataBackend for data.table

Source: R/DataBackendDataTable.R

DataBackend for data.table() as an in-memory data base.

Format

R6Class object inheriting from DataBackend.

Usage

Inherits from DataBackend.

# Construction
b = DataBackendDataTable$new(data, primary_key)
b = as_data_backend(data, primary_key = NULL)

The interface is described in DataBackend.

Arguments

  • data (data.frame()). This includes special data.frames like data.table() or tibble() from package tibble.

  • primary_key (character(1)): Name of the column in data which represents a unique row identifier (as integer or character). If NULL, the constructor as_data_backend() automatically creates an integer column of primary keys.

See also

Other DataBackend: DataBackendMatrix, DataBackend, as_data_backend

Examples

data = as.data.table(iris)
data$id = seq_len(nrow(iris))
b = DataBackendDataTable$new(data = data, primary_key = "id")
print(b)
#> <DataBackendDataTable> (150x6)
#> 
#> Public: colnames, compact_seq, data(), distinct(), formats, hash,
#>   head(), missing(), ncol, nrow, primary_key, rownames
#>    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species id
#> 1:          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa  1
#> 2:          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa  2
#> 3:          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa  3
#> 4:          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa  4
#> 5:          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa  5
#> 6:          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa  6
b$head()
#>    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species id
#> 1:          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa  1
#> 2:          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa  2
#> 3:          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa  3
#> 4:          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa  4
#> 5:          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa  5
#> 6:          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa  6
b$data(rows = 100:101, cols = "Species")
#>       Species
#> 1: versicolor
#> 2:  virginica

b$nrow
#> [1] 150
head(b$rownames)
#> [1] 1 2 3 4 5 6

b$ncol
#> [1] 6
b$colnames
#> [1] "Sepal.Length" "Sepal.Width"  "Petal.Length" "Petal.Width"  "Species"     
#> [6] "id"
